net.sf.freecol.client.gui

Class FontLibrary

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.freecol.client.gui.FontLibrary

  • public class FontLibrary
extends java.lang.Object
    Wraps anything Font related and contains a scale factor. Should be used for getting a Font everywhere it is needed.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  FontLibrary.FontSize
      FontSize allows for choosing the relative size of the Font.
      static class  FontLibrary.FontType
      FontType is used for choosing the typeface of the Font.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      FontLibrary()
      Create a FontLibrary without scaling.
      FontLibrary(float scaleFactor)
      Create a FontLibrary with scaling.

    • Constructor Detail

      • FontLibrary

        public FontLibrary()
        Create a FontLibrary without scaling. Probably not worth using, as you could just use the static methods.

      • FontLibrary

        public FontLibrary(float scaleFactor)
        Create a FontLibrary with scaling. Useful if you need many different fonts.
        Parameters:
        scaleFactor - How much scaling should be applied. Typically the same value as in ImageLibrary.

        Create a scaled Font.
        Parameters:
        fontType - How the font should look like.
        fontSize - Its relative size.
        style - The font style for choosing plain, bold or italic.
        Returns:
        The created Font.

      • createFont

        public static java.awt.Font createFont(FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                       FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize)

      • createFont

        public static java.awt.Font createFont(FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                       FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                       int style)
        Create a Font in rare case one is needed without scaling. Do not use this for normal text, as it leaves out the scaling factor you should get from the appropriate ImageLibrary (there are 3 in use)! Exceptions are currently big headers and things where gui elements are not made flexible enough already to allow a changed size.
        Parameters:
        fontType - How the font should look like.
        fontSize - Its size.
        style - The font style for choosing plain, bold or italic.
        Returns:
        The created Font.

      • createFont

        public static java.awt.Font createFont(FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                       FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                       float scaleFactor)

        public static java.awt.Font createCompatibleFont(java.lang.String string,

        public static java.awt.Font createCompatibleFont(java.lang.String string,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                                 int style)

      • createCompatibleFont

        public static java.awt.Font createCompatibleFont(java.lang.String string,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                                 float scaleFactor)

      • createFont

        public static java.awt.Font createFont(FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                       FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                       int style,
                                       float scaleFactor)
        Create a scaled Font where the scale factor is provided explicitly in the parameter. The equivalent of regular text, which would only complicate the source code and slow down the game if used, would be: createFont(FontType.NORMAL, FontSize.TINY, Font.PLAIN, gui.getImageLibrary().getScalingFactor());
        Parameters:
        fontType - How the font should look like.
        fontSize - Its relative size.
        style - The font style for choosing plain, bold or italic.
        scaleFactor - The applied scale factor.
        Returns:
        The created Font.

      • createCompatibleFont

        public static java.awt.Font createCompatibleFont(java.lang.String string,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontType fontType,
                                                 FontLibrary.FontSize fontSize,
                                                 int style,
                                                 float scaleFactor)
        Create a scaled Font which can display all characters inside the given text string. This is mostly necessary for the header font. Thats because the currently used ShadowedBlack is missing support for CJK and others. Even some special glyphs for European languages like the triple-dot are missing.
        Parameters:
        string - The text to find a compatible font for.
        fontType - How the font should look like.
        fontSize - Its relative size.
        style - The font style for choosing plain, bold or italic.
        scaleFactor - The applied scale factor.
        Returns:
        The created Font.
